subject: RE: [junit] The right amount of testing !?
msgSnippet: No argument, but if the choice is between writing the Customer Test or writing the application-engine-level Programmer Test, I vote for the Customer Test. I
messageBody:
No argument, but if the choice is between writing the Customer Test or writing the application-engine-level Programmer Test, I vote for the Customer Test. I would still have lower-level Programmer Tests to back me up if need be. Ideally, I'd write 'em all.

Take care.

>So said Evett, Charlie on 4/24/2003 --------------------
>The value of the programmer tests comes when the application tests fail.
>Having the unit tests for the underlying engine should make it much easier
>to isolate and fix the problems. Application tests that fail may well be
>an indicator that a new unit test case should be added.
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>Sent: Thursday, April 24, 2003 11:19 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: [junit] The right amount of testing !?
>
>
>I think you need to write the end-to-end (Customer) tests. Ultimately,
>that's what demonstrates the presence of features to the people paying for
>the software. In many cases, there will be a Programmer Test or two that
>tests your application engine in exactly the same way that your Customer
>Test tests your entire application. If you find this to be the case, then
>consider not writing the application engine test and instead test the
>low-level objects. If there is nothing in between -- if your Action
>objects are as low-level as you get -- then live with the duplication.
>Ultimately, you need to test your front end through HTTP.
>
>Take care.
>
>>So said Erik Mattsson on 4/24/2003 --------------------
>>Im finding it hard to find the right amount of testing when I create my
>>tests.
>>
>>Example:
>>I have a http server that receives http requests. These request is in
>>the server split into different actions. The actions can be "login" or
>>"logoff" etc.
>>
>>Actions are seperate classes, which has been tested for "most" possible
>>errors and possibilities. I have one unit testcase for each action.
>>
>>
>>Now im sitting and doing some HTTP-Unit testing of the whole http
>>server, trying to login, logoff, etc. I start the server and connect to
>>it as a real HTTP client, to test the functionality.
>>
>>But somehow I started to create similar tests for each action that Ive
>>already tested (testing the same problems that I did on the action
>>level), which means Im sitting with ALOT of testcases that looks the
>>same but are invoked from different levels. (the action itself is one
>>level, the server is on a higher level)
>>
>>
>>What is the "right" amount of testing, is it best to do the same test
>>but on different levels in order to make sure that NO strange behaviour
>>is discovered or should I just test the whole flow?
>>
>>More tests = better software? ;)
>>//Erik
